Award.AwardTitle: Experimental Measurements of Stresses and Strains of Granular Materials Using 3D Non-Destructive Technologies

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Granular materials have been the subject of extensive research with the objective to capture their constitutive behavior and deformation characteristics. There are two approaches to describe the behavior of granular materials that can be broadly classified as continuum-mechanical and microstructure-based models. The literature lacks a systematic experimental investigation to measure contact forces of compressed/sheared granular particles and their fabric evolution. The proposed research utilizes three-dimensional (3D) nondestructive technologies to capture stresses and strains between sand particles. 3D x-ray diffraction (3DXRD) and Synchrotron Micro-computed Tomography (SMT) scans will be conducted to measure strains and stresses at particle contacts as loading increases for specimens composed of silica sand. Stress-strain relationship, elastic modulus, and stiffness of individual sand particles will be also measured using nano-indenter. Experimental measurements will be compared with discrete element and with microstructure-based constitutive models.

If successful, the results will be used to provide critical measurements, validate and calibrate constitutive discrete and continuum models to better understand the behavior of granular materials. To the best of the PI knowledge, the 3DXRD measurements will be conducted for the first time ever to capture the relationship between stress and strain of individual grains within a bulk mass of natural sand, map the crystallographic orientation, and quantify stresses that cause particle crushing. SMT and 3DXRD are new technologies that have the potential of yielding break-through experimental measurements of stresses and strains of individual particles. The educational plan will include broadening the participation of minority undergraduate students in conducting engineering research, providing enriching research experience for undergraduate engineering students, and developing educational materials tailored for middle and high school student.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
All aspects of soil stability, slope stability, the supporting capacity of deep foundations, and penetration resistance depend on soil strength.  The stress-deformation and stress-deformation-time behavior of soils are of importance in any problem where ground movements are of interest.  In most engineering materials, the strength is derived from internal chemical and physico-chemical forces of interaction, which bond the atoms, molecules, and particles together.  In cohesionless soils such as sand, the stress-strain relationships are mainly derived from inter-particle friction and contact between particles and particle groups and to a lesser extent from particle bonding by weak electrostatic, physico-chemical, and Coulomb forces.

Granular materials (e.g., sand) have been the subject of extensive research with the objective to capture their strength properties and deformation characteristics. The literature lacks a systematic experimental investigation to measure contact forces of compressed/sheared granular particles. The project utilized three-dimensional (3D) nondestructive techniques to measure stresses and strains between sand particles. 3D x-ray diffraction (3DXRD) and Synchrotron Micro-computed Tomography (SMT) scans were conducted to measure strains and stresses at particle contacts as loading increased for specimens composed of silica sand. Stress-strain relationship, elastic modulus, and stiffness of individual sand particles were measured experimentally and was imaged using SMT. Experimental measurements were compared with discrete element method predictions.

The results of the project provide critical experimental measurements, validate and calibrate numerical models to better understand the behavior of granular materials. SMT and 3DXRD are new techniques that yielded break-through experimental measurements of stresses and strains of individual sand particles. The educational plan included broadening the participation of undergraduate students in conducting engineering research and provided enriching research experience for high school students.


Last Modified: 10/28/2013
Modified by: Khalid Alshibli

The stress-deformation and stress-deformation-time behavior of soils are of importance in any problem where ground movements are of interest. In most engineering materials, the strength is derived from internal chemical and physico-chemical forces of interaction, which bond the atoms, molecules, and particles together. In cohesionless soils such as sand, the stress-strain relationships are mainly derived from inter-particle friction and contact between particles and particle groups and to a lesser extent from particle bonding by weak electrostatic, physico-chemical, and Coulomb forces. Granular materials (e.g., sand) have been the subject of extensive research with the objective to capture their strength properties and deformation characteristics. The literature lacks a systematic experimental investigation to measure contact forces of compressed/sheared granular particles. The project utilized three-dimensional (3D) nondestructive techniques to measure stresses and strains between sand particles. 3D x-ray diffraction (3DXRD) and Synchrotron Micro-computed Tomography (SMT) scans were conducted to measure strains and stresses at particle contacts as loading increased for specimens composed of silica sand. Stress-strain relationship, elastic modulus, and stiffness of individual sand particles were measured experimentally and was imaged using SMT. Experimental measurements were compared with discrete element method predictions. The results of the project provide critical experimental measurements, validate and calibrate numerical models to better understand the behavior of granular materials. SMT and 3DXRD are new techniques that yielded break-through experimental measurements of stresses and strains of individual sand particles. The educational plan included broadening the participation of undergraduate students in conducting engineering research and provided enriching research experience for high school students.
